search.query:
| makeresults | eval raw = " path=\"Brisbane---LB\" label=\"3 requests/min
100ms\" good=3 ### path=\"Sydney---LB\" label=\"6 requests/min
100ms\" good=6 ### path=\"Melbourne---LB\" label=\"10 requests/min
100ms\" good=10 ### path=\"LB---IHS001\" label=\"15 requests/min
1ms\" good=15 ### path=\"LB---IHS002\" label=\"4 requests/min
1ms\" good=4 ### path=\"IHS001---APP001\" label=\"\" good=4 ### path=\"IHS001---APP002\" label=\"\" good=2 ### path=\"IHS002---APP001\" label=\"\" good=1 ### path=\"IHS002---APP002\" label=\"\" good=1 ### path=\"APP001---DB\" label=\"4 requests/min
100ms\" good=4 ### path=\"APP002---DB\" label=\"1 requests/min
2334ms\" warn=1 error=1### node=DC1 label=\"Primary DC\" width=400 height=120 labely=-50 opacity=0.2 order=-1 ### node=DC2 label=\"Secondary DC\" width=400 height=120 labely=50 opacity=0.2 order=-2 ### node=LB label=\"F5\" icon=hdd labely=30 height=40 ### node=Brisbane icon=users labely=30 height=40 ### node=Sydney icon=users labely=30 height=40 ### node=Melbourne icon=users labely=30 height=40 ### node=IHS001 icon=server labely=30 height=40 ### node=IHS002 icon=server labely=30 height=40 ### node=APP001 icon=tablet labely=30 height=40 ### node=APP002 icon=tablet labely=30 height=40 ### node=DB icon=database labely=30 height=40 " | makemv delim="###" raw | mvexpand raw | rename raw as _raw | extract

| makeresults | eval raw = " from=ApplicationLicense to=internal good=2 warn=0 error=0 ### from=BucketMover to=internal good=2 warn=0 error=0 ### from=BundlesSetup to=internal good=2 warn=0 error=0 ### from=CMBucketId to=internal good=12 warn=0 error=0 ### from=CertStorageProvider to=internal good=8 warn=0 error=0 ### from=ClientSessionsManager to=internal good=2 warn=0 error=0 ### from=ClusteringMgr to=internal good=4 warn=0 error=0 ### from=DeploymentClient to=internal good=2 warn=2 error=0 ### from=DSManager to=internal good=4 warn=0 error=0 ### from=DS_DC_Common to=internal good=12 warn=0 error=0 " | makemv delim="###" raw | mvexpand raw | rename raw as _raw | extract

panel.html: Some inline CSS styles are in this panel.

div.p: A visualization used for showing the proportion of traffic volume across different links. Inspired by Vizceral by NetFlix. Most often the particles represent an automatically scaled multiple of real traffic volume. Each link can only create 60 particles per second.
Copyright (C) 2020 Chris Younger | Source code | Splunkbase | Questions, Bugs or Suggestions | My Splunk apps

This visualisation expects tabular data, with specific field names. There are two kinds of row data that should be supplied: links and nodes. The link data is identified by having both a from and to field, or a path field. The path field is delimited by three hyphens "---" and can include hops through multiple nodes. The node data will have a node field.
div.h2: Example 1, simple links using from / to fields
div.p: Note that nodes are automatically created.
div.h2: Example 2, same output using path field
div.p: Shared links will have the fields "good", "warn" and "error" automatically summed together
div.h2: Example 3, customise output by adding "node" rows.
div.p: For the users and loadbalancer rows, a custom label is set, along with a font-awesome icon and the label is moved underneath.
Double click a node disable its manual positioning.

By default, the amount of particles shown is automatically ranged/scaled (using linear interpolation) based on the data supplied. The visualization finds the link that has the largest volume of (good + warn + error) and uses that as the upper bound. The formatter option "Particles" > "Data domain", allows manually defining the range that the data is expected to fall into. The value can be set either as a single value representing the maximum (min will default to 0) or a comma seperated pair of numbers (min,max).

Tokens will always be set when clicking on nodes or link labels. Hit "F12" to open browser developer tools, then open the "Console" to observe how tokens are being set. If the data contains a field called "drilldown" this will be included as a token. Nodes: $flow_map_viz-label$, $flow_map_viz-node$, $flow_map_viz-drilldown$, $flow_map_viz-type$ Links: $flow_map_viz-label$, $flow_map_viz-link$, $flow_map_viz-drilldown$, $flow_map_viz-type$, $flow_map_viz-from$, $flow_map_viz-to$ Note that link labels can be used for "drilldowns" to other Splunk dashboards etc. However that as nodes can be dragged to reposition, these can't be used for drilldowns. A work-around for drilldown on nodes, enable the "Advanced" > "HTML Labels" formatter option, and then set the "label" data field to include a html "a" tag to link to your required destination. E.g.  | eval label = "" + node_label + ""
div.h1: Building a complex flow map using a lookup
div.p:
Attemping to set the various node and link options can lead to a messy SPL query. A neat way to solve this is to build a lookup table of all the nodes and links, and then | append it to the end of your real data. If the same link pair exists in multiple rows, then the "good", "warn" and "error" fields will be summed. For other link customisations such as "speed" and "width" the last set property will take effect.
<existing query> | append [|inputlookup my_flowmap_config.csv]
Here is an search that will generate a template CSV file called my_flowmap_config.csv"":
| makeresults count=10
| fillnull value="" node from to height radius opacity position icon good warn error color width distance speed labelx labely fromside toside tooltip label
| table node from to height width radius opacity position icon good warn error color distance speed label labelx labely fromside toside tooltip
| outputlookup my_flowmap_config.csv

tr.td: An ID of node to use as the source of the link.
An ID of node to use as the target of the link.
A series of nodes to link together, seperated by three hypens "---". Should not be specified for the same row that has from/to fields or it will be ignored.
A value representing the volume of good traffic, which will be normalised (by default) and displayed as particles (the "good" color can be set in the formatting options and defaults to dark green).
A value representing the volume of warning traffic, which will be normalised (by default) and displayed as particles (the "warn" color can be set in the formatting options and defaults to orange).
A value representing the volume of error traffic, which will be normalised (by default) and displayed as particles (the "error" color can be set in the formatting options and defaults to red).
Set the color of the line
Set the width of the line
Set the length of the line. This field is redundant if you are manually positioning nodes.
The speed of the particles. Between 1 and 100. Defaults to 90.
Offset the label left and right from the centre of the line. Measured in pixels. Negative values move left.
Offset the label up and down from the centre of the line. Measured in pixels. Negative values move up.
Specify a custom attachment point on the source node. See note [1] below.
Specify a custom attachment point on the target node. See note [1] below.
Specify a custom hover tooltip for the line. Can use HTML if enabled in the formatting options.

Specify a custom label to occur on the line. If "allow HTML" is enabled in formatter options, this field can contain HTML such as
to create a new line.
A field that will be set to token $flow_map_viz-drilldown$ when this link label is clicked.

ul.li: [1] fromside / toside: Possible values are top, bottom, right, left. Defaults to the centre of the node. The value can also be specified with a modifier (+/-) to tune where on that side the attachment occurs. For example: "bottom-10" will attach to the bottom side, 10px to the left of center, "top+20" will attach to the top and 20 pixels to the right of center. When using path with multiple nodes, the fromside only affects the first node and the toside only affects the last node.

tr.td: The ID of a node. Nodes can be disconnected with no links.
A font awesome icon name. From here: https://fontawesome.com/icons?d=gallery&m=free . Defaults to the font-awesome solid icon set (fas). Supply "far ICON" to use font awesome regular.

Set a custom label. If "allow HTML" is enabled in formatter options, this field can contain HTML such as
to create a new line. Defaults to the node ID value.
Offset the label left and right from the centre of the node. Measured in pixels. Negative values move left.
Offset the label up and down from the centre of the node. Measured in pixels. Negative values move up.
The height of the node in pixels.
The width of the node in pixels.
Set the color of the node.
Set the border radius in pixels. Set to the same value as the height and width to make the node a circe.
A comma seperated pair of coordinates. First number is the horizontal position and second is the vertical position as a percentage of available space in the frame. Values should be between 0 and 100
The stacking order of the node. Defaults to 50. Lower numbers stack under higher numbers. A negative value will stack underneath everything else
A field that will be set to token $flow_map_viz-drilldown$ when this node is clicked.
Specify a custom hover tooltip for the node. By default show the Node ID. Can use HTML if enabled in the formatting options.

div.p: The following third-party libraries are used by this app. Thank you!

ul.li: Font Awesome - Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 License - https://fontawesome.com/

panel.html: Basic example using from/to syntax. Nodes are automatically created and use default options set in the formatter configuration.

div.style: font-family: Consolas, "Courier New", monospace; font-weight: normal; font-size: 14px; line-height: 19px; letter-spacing: 0px; color:rgb(212, 212, 212); background-color:rgb(30, 30, 30);padding:10px;margin:5px;

search.query: | table from to good warn error

panel.html: A more complex example that shows how to define node properties in addition to link properties. This example also shows how multiple-links can be specified at once using the "path" syntax. Each node should be delimited by three hypens "---".

If node data is stored in a lookup table, it can be added to an existing query like so:
<existing query> | append [|inputlookup my_table_of_nodes.csv]
.

search.query: | table path node good warn error height width* icon label labely opacity
